												If you're a fan of Pagani and interested in getting into sim racing this is the game for you. While it is lacking in tracks, features and cars that doesn't matter because this is really more of a demo for the full game than anything else.The majority of complaints coming from others about the handling are completely justified because as a racing simulator, Project Cars almost demands a racing wheel to be enjoyed. However with some tweaking of the in game settings you can easily set up a controller to work fairly well. I can't stress the simulation aspect enough as without driving assists the cars on offer can be fairly difficult to control especially because none of the lower powered street cars are available in the demo. The game also tracks tire temperature but fails to explain that for maximum grip to be achieved the tires have to reach a certain temperature (around 100° C) so a minimum of 1 lap needs to be completed before the cars handle properly. The cars on offer all kick side to side when leaving the pit and when quickly accelerating can easily spin out so a controller just won't offer enough degrees of motion to counter act this without assists. I personally use a Logitech G29 with a shifter and in both the full game and this demo the cars are perfectly manageable to drive albeit with some practice.Some people will try and convince you that this is just an arcadey version of Assetto Corsa which simply put it's not. Both games while racing simulators have very different design philosophies and so deciding which one you prefer will really come down to personal preference. A point to consider is that Project Cars has a demo now while Assetto Corsa doesn't. Like the full game however this demo carries over the weather settings from the full game for the race weekends which adds variety, unfortunately car tuning options are not present in the demo as far as I can tell.Considering that Project Cars with all the dlc is still fairly expensive even when on sale, downloading the fairly small demo isn't a bad idea to get an idea whether or not sim racing is for you. If you find you don't like this demo at least you don't need to worry about exceeding your refund period.

Demo to the full game - try it before you buy it.Project CARS - Pagani Edition features a roster of 5 cars - guess what make, and 3 tracks - Monza, Cote D'Azure and the full Nurburgring circuit, and singleplayer practice or quick races with up to 25 opponents.It looks pretty sweet. Car models are perfect but something about their shaders still puts me off, just like Shift 2 Unleashed did. Track detail is great, and overall graphics and visuals are extensively customizable and it seems to run well on a laptop with a quad core i7, 8GB of RAM and a GTX950M GPU without losing its shine.I fire this up sometimes just to hear the amazing roar of 20+ Zonda Cinques launching on Monza. The cars sound properly mental and pretty close to the real thing, but still not quite.It's a simulation racer, and yet it doesn't really handle so well on a gamepad. Cars still have that lightness, bounciness and aggravating oversteering tendency as they did in Shift 2 Unleashed - fittingly, it's the same game engine. Zonda Cinques and Huayras are the limit of my capability to effectively handle them, anything higher is out of my league sadly. It really pushes to be an enthusiast's simulator yet it doesn't feel like a simulator the way, say, Assetto Corsa does.Pre-race settings include setting your opponents' skills, numbers and whether to use the same car or same car class. You can also fiddle with the dynamic weather and day-night cycle, make them faster or slower and such. "Authenticity" settings control the degree of simulation, except it's either the general car assists (antilock brakes, traction control and stability control) or damage, tyre wear and fuel rate. It is stupid to have a garage feature where you can see and "choose" car liveries, if they don't save for the race anyway. I like certain designs better than others, so let me race in those.If you've got a steering wheel set, you should give the Pagani Edition demo a try before making any decision. If you have only a gamepad or keyboard then you should still give it a go, if only for the amazing sound of 24 Cinques launching. I personally am not sold on the delivery of Project CARS.

												Very much reminiscent of the sampler discs you could find at supermarkets and gas stations for the racing games of yesteryear, this makes for a neat little pick-up-and-play affair, containing three tracks (Monza, Azure Coast, and Nurburgring GP + Nordschliefe Combined) and five Pagani vehicles (variants of the Huayra and Zonda). I haven't played the full game and was on the fence about it, and so jumped at the chance to give this a play.I was afraid it'd be a little heavily simulation for my tastes, as I tend to lean firmly towards simcade styles, but it turns out it's pretty heavily adjustable. Coming off of GRID Autosport and Dirt to Daytona, I was rather satisfied with the Amateur settings for the most part. It definitely is an immersive experience, with absolutely glorious sound on headphones and some really solid, detailed vibration + handling on an Xbox 360 controller (I know, I know, it's not a wheel, so sue me. Didn't wanna bother digging the Logitech out). With no rewind function and a rather tricky-to-read (at high speeds anyhow) course map, it definitely is one that wants you to drop everything else and just focus on the race in the moment.The very nicely steady framerate, refreshing lack of aliasing, and, well, the utter lack of the bizarre, disturbing omnipresent sheen that makes the cars look like they were drowned in wax in all the trailers makes for a very smooth visual experience, too. If you have Damage set to Visual and aren't afraid to make contact, though, you'll find this can quickly devolve into a hilarious multi-million-dollar game of bumper cars, the likes of which should make a Need for Speed fan feel right at home. The Huayra is a very satisfying drive, if much too fast and fragile for a usual beginner car, so experience with lots of other racers is recommended. The Zondas, however, I found a bit floaty to use, and skidded off the course with routinely. I'm used to stock cars and ovals, though, so there is bias there.The courses are excellent, and by that I mean 2 out of 3 isn't bad. Monza is a classic course and lives up to the legend, with smartly aggressive AI tactics. Azure Coast is a frantic, scenic point-to-point race. And Nurburgring combined is... well, it's got novelty factor but in practice is an absolutely terrible idea. It takes so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ long to finish a single lap that doing the two laps it has by default actually took me as long as setting up the entire game and finishing both courses before it. It's worth a tour so you can say you've done it, but it isn't actually fun.So I'd say it's absolutely worth a look, even if just for a short while, and piqued my interest in the title it's ripped from. It seems the high degree of customization - especially getting to shut off those garish hovering driver names that take up most of the screen, ugh - makes for a fine little timewaster if you're in the mood for a bit of virtual tourism at high speeds.

												I'm very happy that there was an opportunity to play 'Project Cars' for free, after deliberation on whether to add this to my collection or not, I finally have my answer.It's not going to be a purchase for me.Racing games are held in a market at the moment where the big titles cover pretty much all corners of the racing genre. from Dirt, NFS, Forza, GT. Project Cars offers nor brings anything new to the table, nothing stands out and it does very little to try. Simulation is done better elsewhere as is arcade racing.The graphics on the cars are nice, however it's painfully obvious that's where the team have spent most of their time. Something with the reverse of some of the cars is also off, they seem to have the turning circle of a cruise ship. 												A misguided racing simulator that doesn't warn buyers of it's brutally realistic handling.~I'm thankful to be able to try this game for free. And I know - being a demo - not many features will not be finished/present. But as soon as I started, I could see this game's biggest problem.Now before I begin; let me make it clear that I'm not saying that this game is bad. It's just for a select few - hence me not recommending it. Read my NOTE at the bottom for a difficulty comparison with DiRT 3.~I've played handfuls of simulators, and done my fair share of real-world racing in a variety of vehicles and environments, and from that I can tell that there's a massive amount of attention paid to how the cars handle in this game - and it's punishing. Even with a controller (Xbox 360) and a gentle driving style, I was constantly battling over/understeer, torque steering, fish tailing, and other handling troubles that real-world racers face. Now that's not a complaint, as it was very realistic and fully tested by skills (more than any other game/simulator I'd played)... ...but having a demo - the thing that's meant to get people interested - set on one of the most narrow and punishing tracks in the world (the Nurburgring) is asking for trouble. Especially when you put them in a ridiculously light, fast and overpowered Zonda racecar. Even the hosts of Topgear would struggle to handle such a beast, despite their day job of reviewing cars (many of them, supercars).~So, in short: Unless you are a HARDCORE racer who's done and dusted with all your other games of this kind - I'd advise leaving this particular one alone.NOTE: Just as a yardstick to compare my gaming skill level with your own - I can achieve 1st place in almost every event of DiRT 3 at full difficulty (no assists), and I could barely drive at a reasonable speed with even the slowest Zonda. 												edit: Ok I think it's good to be able to admit when you're wrong and I'm doing that now.  I decided to give this another go, and found some tweaks which really made the FFB come alive and I'm shocked to say, felt BETTER than some sims in some regards.  For example I love how understeer is handled, with the wheel vibrating, you can almost feel a physical front tire fighting for grip.  Once the FFB feels good then the physics start feeling better too and I've thoroughly enjoyed a couple laps around the nordschliefe in the zonda R. Would definitely consider buying the full game if it comes up on sale.  So I'm changing this to a thumbs up.  If you'd like to know the tweaks I made, just google 'Jack spades FFB tweaker files' and you'll find the thread which gives all the instructions.Got halfway through the nordshliefe before I hit the exit button.  I have a T300 and the FFB is just horribly lifeless, what I mostly feel is center spring and virtually nothing else.  I lowered the gain so I know I'm not clipping.  There is a very detailed FFB settings section, but to be honest I'm not going to spend hours of my life experimenting to try and improve.  I really feel it should give adequate FFB out the box for a very mainstream wheel.Perhaps if I could feel the physics model had something to be excited about I might want to spend the time tweaking the FFB, but it just doesn't feel right to me, both understeer and oversteer are handled in a weird unrealistic way. Also the much vaunted graphics don't impress me very much, I much prefer the crispness of Rfactor2, Automobista and Iracing. (yeh I just said that!) If you want realistic handling, the sim that has impressed me the most is Automobilista. (which I base on real-life experience)
